Rohi @ Satish Kalya @ Satish Tangapan ... vs The Central Bureau Of Investigation And ... on 14 February, 2020

Author: Prithviraj K. Chavan

Bench: Prithviraj K. Chavan

                                          criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc



Shailaja

           IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT BOMBAY

                   CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION

Mr. S.G. Rajput a/w Aditya Jadhav a/w Chaitali Rajput a/w Nivida Mohite,
for the Applicant in I.A. No.1 of 2019 in Appeal No.1201 of 2019.

Mr. Aniket Vagal, for the Applicant in I.A. No.1 of 2019 in Appeal No.1263
of 2019.

Mr. Santosh Deshpande, for the Applicant in I.A. No.1 of 2019 in Appeal
No.1295 of 2019.

Mr. Pradeep Gharat, Special P.P, for Respondent-C.B.I.

Ms. M.R. Tidke, for the Respondent-State.
                                   ....
             CORAM             :    PRITHVIRAJ K. CHAVAN, J.
     RESERVED ON               :    27th JANUARY, 2020.
PRONOUNCED ON                  :    14th FEBRUARY, 2020.

P.C:
                 By these applications referred hereinabove, the applicants have

prayed for their release, pending hearing and final disposal of the appeals

filed by them.



2.               The Special Court constituted under Maharashtra Control of

Organised Crime Act (for short 'MCOC Act') by a judgment and order

dated 20th August, 2019 in MCOC Special Case No.2 of 2013 and MCOC

Special Case No.7 of 2017, convicted and sentenced the applicants as

follows:

       [1] The accused No.1 Nityanand Narayan Nayak, accused No.2

             Selvin Challapan Danial, accused no.3 Rohi @ Satish Kalya

             @ Satish Tangapan Joseph, accused No.4 Dilip Atmaram

             Upadhyay, accused No.5 Talvinder Singh Gurubacchan


                                                                                              2/10



       ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                       ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                              criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




           Singh Bakshi @ Sonu and accused No.6 Rajendra Sadashiv

           Nikalje @           Chhota Rajan @ Nana @ Seth @ Sir are

           convicted as per section 235 (2) of Cr. P.C. 1973, for the

           offence punishable u/s 120 (B) r/w 307 IPC r/w Section 3, 25

           and 27 of the Arms Act r/w section 3 (1) (ii), 3(2) and 3(4) of

           the MCOC Act, 1999.



     [2] The accused No.1 Nityanand Narayan Nayak, accused No.2

           Selvin Challapan Danial, accused no.3 Rohi @ Satish Kalya

           @ Satish Tangapan Joseph, accused No.4 Dilip Atmaram

           Upadhyay, accused No.5 Talvinder Singh Gurubacchan

           Singh Bakshi @ Sonu and accused No.6 Rajendra Sadashiv

           Nikalje @ Chhota Rajan @ Nana @ Seth @ Sir are

           sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for a period of

           eight years each with fine of Rs.5,00,000/-, in default, to

           suffer rigorous imprisonment for one year each for the

           offences punishable u/s 120 (B) r/w 307 of IPC and section 3

           (1) (ii) of the MCOC Act, 1999.



3.             Heard Mr. Rajput, learned Counsel for the applicant in I.A.

No.1 of 2019 in Appeal No.1201 of 2019, Mr. Vagal, learned Counsel for

the applicant in I.A. No.1 of 2019 in Appeal No.1263 of 2019, Mr.


                                                                                             3/10



     ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                        ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                             criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




Deshpande, learned Counsel for the applicant in I.A. No.1 of 2019 in

Appeal No.1295 of 2019 and Mr. Gharat, Special Public Prosecutor for

C.B.I and Ms. Tidke, A.P.P, for State.



4.             The applicants are said to be the members of an Organized

Crime Syndicate of Chhota Rajan. It is submitted that there is no evidence,

much less, believable evidence whether the weapon used was a pistol or

revolver. Learned Counsel for the applicants took me through the evidence

of prosecution witnesses. It is contended that almost all the confessions of

the applicants are copies of each other including the errors and stereotyped

record which creates doubt as to the authenticity and genuineness of the

confession recorded by the concerned D.C.Ps.              It is contended that no

material is produced by which it can be said that the applicants were

produced before the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate as well as there is no

evidence establishing the identity of the assailants.


5.             So far as applicant-Talvinder Singh Gurubacchan Singh Bakshi

@ Sonu is concerned, no description has been given of the applicant by the

identifying witness. C.C.T.V footage produced on record is sans a certificate

required under section 65B of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (for short

'Evidence Act'). The prosecution has failed to establish the exact spot of the

incident, as different witnesses have shown different spots, more



                                                                                            4/10



     ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                       ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                              criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




particularly, the injured was not taken to the spot even after his discharge

from the Hospital.


6.              The prosecution has not even proved an F.I.R through the

victim i.e P.W.28-B.R. Shetty which came to be proved through the

Investigating Officer. The most important aspect of the case is that the

prosecution has not established motive behind the offence.


7.              Owner of the Motorcycle alleged to have been used in the

offence has not been examined. P.W.34- D.C.P Dhananjay Kulkarni is said

to have been admitted the repeated mistakes in the confessional statements.

The prosecution has failed to recover weapon of the offence which is said to

have been thrown in Vashi Creek.        Even the testimony of P.W.37- Mr.

Narkar Naib Tahesildar suffers from several discrepancies.                         So far as

applicant No.4 is concerned, it is contended that the evidence against this

applicant-accused is shaky and incredible.



8.             As already stated, there is no discovery of weapon from Vashi

creek by the Police, in the sense, Panchanama under section 27 of the

Evidence Act has not been established.          There is remote possibility of

identifying the assailant/s in the rear view mirror of the car during night

hours. The sanction for prosecution given by P.W.41-Dr. Satyapal Singh

also suffers from irregularities.

                                                                                             5/10



     ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                        ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                               criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




9.              On the other hand, the learned A.P.P objected the release of the

applicants, pending the appeal on the ground that even if no weapon has

been seized, there is no reason to disbelieve the informant P.W.28-B.R.

Shetty as regards fire opened by A4 and A5 in the light of the fact that the

informant had given description of the assailant.                 He submits that the

reasoning rendered by the trial Court cannot be falsified at this stage or can

be negated. There is strong unrebuttable evidence, according to the learned

A.P.P, which is in the form of CDR indicating presence of applicants in the

vicinity where the offence had occurred. The applicants had seen the poster

of the victim and that is how they could ascertain his identity, meaning

thereby, they did reconnaissance.


10.             It was the case of the contract killing at the behest of Gangster

Chhota Rajan. Merely because there are certain similarities in the first part

of the confessional statement does not mean that the statements are copies

of each other. Rather, according to the learned A.P.P, there is consistency in

all the confessional statements which are well corroborated with each other.

According to the learned A.P.P, part (I) of the confession is a format

commonly used and, therefore, there might be certain similarities in the

mistakes/errors but that would not go to the root of the prosecution case.


11.             Having heard the respective Counsel for the applicants as well

as the learned A.P.P, without going into the merits, it is pertinent to note that

                                                                                              6/10



      ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                        ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                             criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




the applicants have already undergone more than six years of incarceration

in Jail. Those being appeals of 2019 and looking to the pendency of the old

appeals on the file of this Court, it is quite unlikely that the present appeals

would be taken up for final disposal in near future.


12.             The applicant No.1 came to be arrested on 20th October, 2012

and applicant No.2 came to be arrested on 23rd October, 2012. Applicant

No.3 came to be arrested on 26th November, 2012.


13.             Maximum sentence awarded by the trial Court in view of the

impugned judgment and order of conviction is 8 years. The applicants have

already undergone substantial part of the substantive sentence. The Hon'ble

Supreme Court in the case of Kiran Kumar Vs. State of M.P, (2001) 9

Supreme Court Cases 211 made it clear that it is the normal rule that when

the appeal of a person convicted and sentenced is pending, the sentence

passed on him should be suspended unless any exceptional reason recorded

in the impugned order and, therefore, the Hon'ble Supreme Court suspended

the sentence and directed the release of the applicant on bail. The Hon'ble

Supreme Court while dealing with sections 389 and 374 of the Code of

Criminal Procedure took into consideration it's judgment in the case of

Bhagwan Rama Shinde Gosavi Vs. State of Gujarat, (1999) 4 Supreme

Court Cases 421 wherein it has been observed that when a person is

convicted and sentenced to a short-term imprisonment, can be released on

                                                                                            7/10



      ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                      ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                                  criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




bail as a normal rule when the appeal is pending. The sentence should be

suspended and it's rejection should be only by way of exception. In such

cases, every endeavour should be made to have the appeal posted for early

hearing and disposal.            It is observed that if the short-term sentence is

allowed to run out during the pendency of the appeal, the appeal itself will

become, for all practical purposes, infructuous so far as the appellant is

concerned.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)


14.             Learned Counsel for the applicants have drawn my attention to

an order passed by this Court (Coram: Dama Seshadri Naidu, J.) in

Criminal Application No.591 of 2019 in Criminal Appeal No.136 of 2019

wherein similar view has been echoed by the learned Single Judge. My

attention is also drawn to a judgment of the Division Bench of this Court in

Criminal Application No.1312 of 2018 in Criminal Appeal No.934 of 2018

dated 20th February, 2020 (Coram: A.S. Oka and A.S. Gadkari, JJ) which

was also a case under MCOC Act wherein the Division Bench of this Court

took a similar view while suspending the substantive sentence, pending the

appeal.


15.             Having considered the overall circumstances, the prayer of the

applicants needs to be granted. Now, to the order.



                                                                                                 8/10



      ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020                           ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
                                        criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc




                               : ORDER:

[1] Pending the hearing and final disposal of Appeal Nos.1201 of 2019, 1263 of 2019 and 1295 of 2019, execution of the substantive sentence inflicted upon the applicants shall stand suspended.

[2] Till final disposal of the appeals, each of the applicants shall furnish a P.R. bond in the sum of Rs.30,000/- with two solvent local sureties in the like amount to the satisfaction of the learned Special Judge under MCOC, Mumbai. [3] The release of the applicants on bail is further granted on the condition that the applicants shall, on the first Monday commencing from 2nd March, 2020 and then July of every calendar year till disposal of the appeals shall report to the Special Judge at 11.00 a.m. In case, the aforesaid Mondays are Court holidays then the applicants shall report on the next working day of the Court.

[4] In the event of any single default committed by any of the applicants, the learned Special Judge shall immediately submit a report to that effect to the Registrar (Judicial-1) of this Court who shall immediately place the report before the appropriate Bench for passing necessary orders. 9/10 ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::

criminal appeal No.1201-2019 with companion appeals.doc [5] The applicants are directed to deposit 50% of the fine amount in the trial Court, if not already deposited, within two months of passing of this order.

[6] The applicants shall not, in any manner, establish or attempt to contact the victim or his family members. The applications stand disposed of in the aforesaid terms.

[PRITHVIRAJ K. CHAVAN, J.] 10/10 ::: Uploaded on - 14/02/2020 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2020 15:36:43 :::
